Understate: The claim may understate the recommended rate of caesarean section deliveries by the World Health Organization, as the expert mentions that the 10% threshold is widely cited but not a formal recommendation.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it is based on a single study from 2019, which may not provide a comprehensive picture of the current prevalence of caesarean section delivery in Nigeria.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may have alternative explanations for the low prevalence of caesarean section deliveries in Nigeria, such as regional differences and the community-based nature of the survey.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the national prevalence of caesarean section delivery in Nigeria is about 2.1%, as supported by the cited study.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption that increasing the rate of caesarean section deliveries in Nigeria is necessary to save lives, without considering other factors or potential risks associated with higher rates.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance of the low prevalence of caesarean section deliveries in Nigeria as an indication of under-utilization of the service, without considering other factors that may contribute to the decision-making process for childbirth.
